newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Seoul to let private groups to expand aid to North.
newsitem.headline: Seoul to let private groups to expand aid to North.

text.p: South Korea will allow local business groups to supply food to North Korea as part of steps to expand aid to the impoverished state, the National Unification Ministry said on Monday.
The ministry confirmed that it will lift a ban on private organisations providing rice to North Korea.

Lee Jong-riol, director-general at the ministry's humanitarian affairs bureau, told reporters that South Korea's Red Cross would remain the only channel for the private sector's food aid to North Korea.
He said South Korean companies could contribute aid to various business groups, which will then pass on to the Red Cross for delivery to the North.

Religious and human rights groups in South Korea have been permitted to ship other food aid to the North but Seoul has in the past banned shipments of rice, saying it could be diverted to the military.

Monday's move is the latest goodwill gesture by South Korea which is trying to lure the North to four-nation peace talks jointly proposed by U.S. President Bill Clinton and South Korean President Kim Young-sam last April. The fourth participant in the talks is China.
